Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: US Ignite: Wireless Research Consortium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this project, US Ignite expects to accelerate the development and adoption of compelling next-generation wireless network technologies that will transform people's lives, by virtue of the creation of a Wireless Research Consortium composed of a diverse set of partners in industry, private foundations, research and education networks, cities and regions, researchers, venture capitalists, and software developers. The project will culminate in the national launch of the US Ignite Wireless Research Consortium, which will include announcements about the National Science Foundation-led deployment, partner commitments, and proposed long-term governance model of a series of advanced wireless research initiatives.

The proposed Wireless Research Consortium is critical to advancing wireless network knowledge and understanding, since no such coordinated partnership focused on the support of long-term research exists at present. The next-generation of wireless networks is changing the landscape for what networked applications can do. The proposed partnership anticipates significant impacts when transferring knowledge among partners from research to practice. Given the groundswell of interest in next-generation wireless network technologies, US Ignite will extend partnerships to numerous partners who can, in turn, give access to their diverse skill sets, expertise, and resources, with a view to share them with NSF-funded researchers. The current US Ignite management team brings 85 collective years of academic, industry, and government leadership and start-up experience to the project, and will leverage this experience to build the Wireless Research Consortium.

POR.DRECONTENT:
US Ignite, in collaboration with the National Science Foundation (NSF), conducted a project to help plan and launch a public-private, advanced wireless research consortium called Platforms for Advanced Wireless Research (PAWR).  Accomplishments for this project in terms of each primary activity were as follows:

1.Begin outreach to corporations, organizations, and researchers in the wireless networking space to ensure understanding of the proposed consortium. Over the course of this project, US Ignite arranged for calls and meetings with over 40 organizations among wireless carriers, wireless chip manufacturers, device manufacturers, RAN and core network equipment manufacturers, wireless software and operating system companies, testing and technology companies, and wireless associations.  

2.Explain the benefits of the proposed consortium to corporations, foundations, and other potential funders or resource providers. In partnership with NSF, US Ignite created outreach materials that were used in one-on-one meetings to convey the benefits of the proposed consortium. In addition, such materials were used during meetings with potential consortium members at the White House on April 25, 2016 and at NSF on May 23, 2016 to build further commitment to the program.

3.Secure commitment of funders and resource providers as partners in the consortium. US Ignite developed language for Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) and negotiated with potential consortium members to execute the MOUs in advance of the July 15, 2016 launch of the Platforms for Advanced Wireless Research (PAWR) program. 

4.Negotiate commitment language with consortium partners to ensure readiness for public announcement. Twenty-one organizations signed MOUs prior to July 15, with an additional four signing by the end of September 2016. Cash and in-kind contributions from these 25 organizations totaled over $40 million. All organizations committed to language included within the public announcement of the $100 million public-private partnership to help drive technological breakthroughs in the wireless industry.  Organizations that joined the PAWR consortium included Anritsu, AT&T, Carlson Wireless, CommScope, Crown Castle, Ericsson, FiberTower, HTC, Intel, Interdigital, Juniper, Keysight Technologies, National Instruments, Nokia, Oracle, Qualcomm, Samsung, Shared Spectrum, Sprint, T-Mobile, Verizon, Viavi Solutions,  ATIS, CTIA, and TIA.

5.Help arrange logistics for a summer 2016 launch event. In partnership with NSF,  US Ignite helped plan, recruit participants for and deliver the PAWR launch event on July 15, 2016. Efforts included presentations during the event, facilitation of a Q & A session, and launch of the original PAWR website and social media amplification. Eight major publications (i.e., Fortune, US Today, PC World, etc.) published articles about PAWR.  After the launch event between July 2016 and March 2017, US Ignite helped establish governance structures for the PAWR Industry Consortium, conducted monthly calls and produced written materials for eventual inclusion in the PAWR Request for Proposals.

Overall, the accomplishments described above met the key goals of the PAWR program, which were to establish the groundwork for enhancing wireless research capabilities in the US to increase number of potentially disruptive research efforts and speed time-to-market. Other impacts supported by this initial launch of the PAWR program include:

  • Helping to continue/sustain U.S. leadership
  • Addressing significant pre-competitive research challenges; not easily feasible for individual companies
  • Creating wide-scale, heterogeneous, real-time testing environments for new concepts
  • Expanding pool of wireless experts through education, training, and nurturing of today’s students
  • Enhancing industry-academic partnerships and ultimately technology commercialization
